titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: George F. Sproule was born in Ireland in 1867. In 1884, Sproule entered the office of Board of Port Wardens of Philadelphia as a Vessel Clerk. 1888, he was elected secretary of the Board of Port Wardens and served in this role until the Board was abolished in 190. Sproule served for 12 years as secretary of the Commissioners of Navigation, which replaced the Board of Port Wardens. In 1920, he was appointed by Mayor J. Hampton Moore to serve as Director of Wharves, Docks and Ferries. Sproule married Nora Louise Gerrish in 1896 and lived in Overbrook. He died in 1928. Sproule was responsible for much of the development of the Port of Philadelphia, improvements to Delaware Avenue and construction of municipal piers. George F. Sproule, compiler of The port of Philadelphia: its facilities and advantages, published by the Board of Commissioners of Navigation for the River Delaware and its Navigable Tributaries, 1914 (HSP has this)

scopecontent.p: Collection of scrapbooks, photo albums, and papers of George F. Spoule. Scrapbooks contain period newspaper clippings and related ephemera, relating to George F. Sproule's professional career with the Port of Philadelphia. Also scrapbooks of Philadelphia Shipping News clippings. The scrapbooks date from the end of 1884 to 1928. Photo albums include: images from a trip taken by the Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce, US Congress,aboard the pilot-boat Philadelphia in 1911; and photos of the Raritan Canal taken during an inspection by the Rivers and Harbors Committee of the US Congress, 1911. Other photographs in the collection include: portraits of Sproule; pictures of Sproule and other members of several committees; images the Municipal Piers constructed by the Department of Docks Wharves and Ferries, ca. 1920s; images of Delaware Ave, 1890s; images of various ships on the Delaware River, including the John Wanamaker. Papers in the collection include cards, passes, programs, legal briefs, speeches, invitations, letters, manuscripts, and typescripts, related to the career of George F. Sproule, dated 1887 to 1927. A number of these items also document the history of the city and the Port of Philadelphia. Additional materials include: two appointment books of George F. Sproul, 1926-1927; and letters and documents and photographs and newspaper clippings related to the career of S. Jackson Sproule as Port of Philadelphia representative during WWII.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
